heading: gates: 'we'll make concessions'
subheading: the microsoft chairman tells shareholders the company will try to meet us demands, but probably no more than halfway.
author: reuters
text: bill gates told microsoft shareholders on wednesday that the software giant was willing to go "a long way" to meet government demands in its current federal antitrust case. speaking at the company's annual meeting, gates added, however, that microsoft "cannot back off" its need to add new internet-related features to its widely-used windows operating system.also:more from lycosjudge jackson: linux won't lastjudge: 'gates was main culprit'judge lowers boom on mswho thinks what about thatin praise or contempt of msus v. microsoft: timelinejudge jackson's findings of factongoing us v. microsoft coverageresponding to a shareholder's question, bob herbold, microsoft's chief operating officer, said the company "had seen nothing" in the federal judge's opinion issued last week that would justify breaking up the company, one of the available remedies should microsoft lose its case.late friday, us judge thomas penfield jackson ruled the software company a monopoly, saying that it bullied rivals and hurt consumers by stifling competition in the arena for personal computer operating systems.the judge still must rule on a remedy, but it may take months or even years in settlement talks and legal appeals before the case is finally resolved.microsoft shares, which have fallen since friday's decision, were off 11/16 at 88-3/16 by mid-afternoon on the nasdaq.copyright
